verb.relation

description::
· relation-verb is a-verb that denotes a-relation.
· in English a-relation-verb cannot-be-used in continuous-tenses.

name::
* McsEngl.relation-verb,
* McsEngl.state-verb,
* McsEngl.stative-verb,
* McsEngl.verb.relation,

descriptionLong::
"The term equative (or equational) is used in linguistics to refer to constructions where two entities are equated with each other. For example, the sentence Susan is our president, equates two entities "Susan" and "our president". In English, equatives are typically expressed using a copular verb such as "be", although this is not the only use of this verb. Equatives can be contrasted with predicative constructions where one entity is identified as a member of a set, such as Susan is a president. This view has been contrasted by Otto Jespersen in the first part of the XX century and by Giuseppe Longobardi and Andrea Moro in the second. In particular, Andrea Moro in 1988 proved that either DP must be non referential in the sense of Geach (1962) by exploiting arguments based on binding theory. The idea is that when a DP plays the role of predicate it enlarges its binding domain: for example, in John met his cook the pronoun can refer to the subject John but in John is his cook it cannot. The key-step was to admit that the DP following the copula can be referential whereas the one preceding must not, in other words the key-step was to admit that there can be inverse copular sentences, namely those where the subject, which is referential, follows the predicate. For a discussion starting from Moro's data see Heycock (2012). For a historical view of the development of the analysis of the copula see Moro
Different world languages approach equatives in different ways. The major difference between languages is whether or not they use a copular verb or a non-verbal element (e.g. demonstrative pronoun) to equate the two expressions.
The term equative is also sometimes applied to comparative-like constructions in which the degrees compared are identical rather than distinct: e.g., John is as stupid as he is blonde; some languages have a separate equative case."
[{2021-10-10 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equative]

verb.phrasal

description::
· multiword-verb is a-verb with its content-part comprised of many words.
· like the-multiword-nouns what makes a-phrase a-multiword-verb is the-existance of a-VerbCnpt with name this phrase.
· for example, the-expression "have-the-opinion" and the-verb "think" denote the-same thing and thus are synonyms.

name::
* McsEngl.compound-verb!⇒verbPhrasal,
* McsEngl.multiword-verb!⇒verbPhrasal,
* McsEngl.periphrastic-verb!⇒verbPhrasal,
* McsEngl.phrasal-verb!⇒verbPhrasal,
* McsEngl.verb.multiword!⇒verbPhrasal,
* McsEngl.verbPhrasal,
====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.πολυλεκτικό-ρήμα!το!=verbPhrasal,

generic-tree::
* multiword-term,

descriptionLong::
"Multi-word verbs are verbs that consist of more than one word.[1] This term may cover both periphrasis as in combinations involving modal or semi-modal auxiliaries with an additional verbal or other lexeme, e.g. had better, used to, be going to, ought to, phrasal verbs, as in combinations of verbs and particles,[2] and compound verbs as in light-verb constructions, e.g. take a shower, have a meal."
[{2023-05-11 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-word_verb]

verb.light

description::
"The term ‘light verb’ (LV), coined by Jespersen (1954), refers to verbs such as have and give in complex predicate constructions like have a bath and give a push, where the main semantic content is provided not by the verb, but by the action nominal, for example bath and push. In a general sense, the light verb construction (LVC) have a bath roughly means bathe. From a typological perspective, LVCs have close historical association with their independent verb counterparts (see Butt 2003; Butt and Lahiri 2002, among others)."
[{2021-11-30 retrieved} https://www.soas.ac.uk/linguistics/research/workingpapers/volume-18/file115990.pdf]

name::
* McsEngl.light-verb,
* McsEngl.verb.light,

conjunction-name of HmnmLogoView

description::
· conjunction-of-HmnmLago is a-term that denotes a-conjunction-cpt (a-directed-timeless-relation).
===
"In grammar, a conjunction (abbreviated conj or cnj) is a part of speech that connects words, phrases, or clauses that are called the conjuncts of the conjunctions. The term discourse marker is mostly used for conjunctions joining sentences. This definition may overlap with that of other parts of speech, so what constitutes a "conjunction" must be defined for each language. In English a given word may have several senses, being either a preposition or a conjunction depending on the syntax of the sentence (for example, "after" being a preposition in "he left after the fight" versus it being a conjunction in "he left after they fought"). In general, a conjunction is an invariable (noninflected) grammatical particle and it may or may not stand between the items conjoined.
The definition may also be extended to idiomatic phrases that behave as a unit with the same function, e.g. "as well as", "provided that".
A simple literary example of a conjunction: "the truth of nature, and the power of giving interest". (Samuel Taylor Coleridge's Biographia Literaria)[1]
Conjunctions may be placed at the beginning of sentences:[2] "But some superstition about the practice persists".[3]"
[{2019-08-18} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunction_(grammar)]

name::
* McsEngl.Conjname!⇒HmnmConj,
* McsEngl.HmnmConj!=conjunction-of-lagoHmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'conjunction!⇒HmnmConj,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-conjunction!⇒HmnmConj,
* McsEngl.cnjHmnm!⇒HmnmConj,

syntax of HmnmConj

description::
· the-structure of a-conjunction with its arguments.

* noun-phrase:
· _stxEngl: [_stxSbj:[[Lilacs] [(and) violets]] _stxVrb:{are} _stxFrequency:[usually] _stxSbjc:[purple].]

* adverbial:
_syntaxEngl: [_stxSbj:[She] _stxVrb:{looked} _stxDirection:[(at) the papers] _stxSpace:[(around) her].] [HarperCollins]
_syntaxZhon: _stxManner:[[慢慢](地)] _stxVrb:{走}. mànmàn de zǒu. != slowly walk.
_syntaxZhon: _stxVrb:{飞} _stxManner:[(得)[快]]. fēi de kuài. != fly quickly.

* sentence-system:
· _stxEngl: [[I'm 53] [(and) I'm very happy].] [HarperCollins]

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmConj'syntax,
* McsEngl.syntax.HmnmConj,

HmnmConj.adposition

description::
· adposition is a-conjunction with ONE argument.
· conjunctions denote relations which have at least TWO arguments.
· adpositions denote spaces and times RELATIVE to other spaces of times, so the-other argument is-understood from the-context.
===
"Prepositions and postpositions, together called adpositions (or broadly, in English, simply prepositions),[1] are a class of words used to express spatial or temporal relations (in, under, towards, before) or mark various semantic roles (of, for).[2]"
[{2019-11-14} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preposition_and_postposition]

name::
* McsEngl.adposition,
* McsEngl.HmnmConj.adposition,

* McsEngl.preposition-or-postposition,

preposition.English (link)

preposition.Greek

description::
"Οι προθέσεις είναι:
α) 5 μονοσύλλαβες: με, σε, για, ως (σπάνια ως), προς,
β) 7 δισύλλαβες: κατά, μετά, παρά, αντί(ς), από, δίχως, χωρίς.
γ) 1 τρισύλλαβη: ίσαμε."
[ΝΕΟΕΛΛΗΝΙΚΗ ΓΡΑΜΜΑΤΙΚΗ, ΟΕΔΒ 1987, 197]
"Στα μαθηματικά χρησιμοποιούμαι τις αρχαίες προθσεις:
συν, επί, δια, πλην, μείον."
[ΝΕΟΕΛΛΗΝΙΚΗ ΓΡΑΜΜΑΤΙΚΗ, ΟΕΔΒ 1987, 199]
"Από τις προθσεις τσσερεις, οι με, σε, για, από είναι συχνότατες και χουν ποικίλες σημασίες. Άλλες, καθώς οι προς, μετά, παρά, δίχως χουν περιορισμνη χρήση."
[ΝΕΟΕΛΛΗΝΙΚΗ ΓΡΑΜΜΑΤΙΚΗ, ΙΜΤ 1978 (1941), 388]
===
"Σε μερικές περιπτώσεις λέγονται και οι αρχαίες προθέσεις:
δια, εκ, εξ, εν, επί, περί, προ, υπέρ, υπό."

name::
* McsEngl.Greek-preposition!⇒prepEll,
* McsEngl.prepEll,
* McsEngl.preposition.Greek!⇒prepEll,

conjSentence.subordinating

description::
· "A subordinating conjunction is a word or phrase that links a dependent clause to an independent clause. This word or phrase indicates that a clause has informative value to add to the sentence’s main idea, signaling a cause-and-effect relationship or a shift in time and place between the two clauses."
[{2023-07-21 retrieved} https://www.grammarly.com/blog/subordinating-conjunctions/]

name::
* McsEngl.conjSentence.subordinating!⇒conjSubordinating,
* McsEngl.conjSubordinating,
* McsEngl.subordinating-conjunction!⇒conjSubordinating,
====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.σύνδεσμος.υποτακτικός!=conjSubordinating,
* McsElln.υποτακτικός-σύνδεσμος!ο!=conjSubordinating,

conjSentence.subordinatingNo

description::
· connects independent only or dependent only sentences.

name::
* McsEngl.conjSentence.subordinatingNo,
====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.σύνδεσμος.παρατακτικός!=conjSentence.subordinatingNo,

HmnmConj.English (link)

HmnmConj.Sinago (link)

HmnmConj.Esperanto

description::

argo-phrase of HmnmLogoView

description::
· ondo-system of HmnmLago is a-logo-node that denotes an-ArgoCnpt-system.

name::
* McsEngl.logo-node.ondoname-phrase!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-ondoname-phrase!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.logo-ondoname-syst!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.logo-ondo-system--of-HmnmLago!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.HmnmArgo-phrase--of-HmnmLago!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.ondo-phrase!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.ondo-system--of-HmnmLago!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.phrase.ondo!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo, {2023-05-14},
* McsEngl.phraseOndoHmn!⇒phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.systOndo!⇒phraseOndo,

modifier of phraseOndo

description::
· ondoname-modifier is the-logo-node that ADDS information to a-main-noun.

name::
* McsEngl.modifier-of-phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.HmnmArgo-modifier,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo'modifier,

phraseOndo.SPECIFIC

description::
* NounmbrMain-NounmbrMain--phraseOndo,
* NounmbrMain-case--phraseOndo,
* NounmbrMain-adjective--phraseOndo,
* NounmbrMain-adverb--phraseOndo,
* NounmbrMain-adjective-adverb--phraseOndo,
* NounmbrMain-conjunction--phraseOndo,
* NounmbrMain-sentence--phraseOndo,
===
* title--phraseOndo,
* verb-argument--phraseOndo,

name::
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.specific,

phraseOndo.noun-noun

description::
· noun-noun--ondo-system is an-ondo-system of a-noun with another noun.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[The musician Harry Connick] _stxVrb:{will come} _stxSpace:[(to) Champaign]. [restrictive appositive]
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[Harry Connick, the musician,] _stxVrb:{will come} _stxSpace:[(to) Champaign]. [non-restrictive appositive]
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[My brother the research associate] _stxVrb:{works} _stxSpace:[(at) a large polling firm].


· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[a car's color] _stxVrb:{is} _stxSbjc:[ridiculous] _stxTime:[some times].

name::
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-noun,

phraseOndo.noun-adjective

description::
· noun-adjective--ondo-system is an-ondo-system of a-noun with an-adjective-ondoname.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[There] _stxVrb:{are} _stxSbjc:[beautiful beaches] _stxSpace:[(near) Santiago].
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[my house] _stxVrb:{collapsed}.

name::
* McsEngl.noun-adjective--phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-adjective,

phraseOndo.noun-adverb

description::
· noun-adverb--ondo-system is an-ondo-system of a-noun with an-adverb-noun.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[the road ahead] _stxVrb:{is} _stxSbjc:[foggy].

name::
* McsEngl.noun-adverb-phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-adverb,

phraseOndo.noun-adjective-adverb

description::
· noun-adjective-adverb--ondo-system is an-ondo-system of a-noun with an-adjective-ondo and an-adverb.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[A squinting modifier] _stxVbr:(is) _stxSbjc:[[an ambiguously placed modifier] (that) [can modify either the word before it or the word after it]].

name::
* McsEngl.noun-adjective-adverb-phraseOndo,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-adjective-adverb,

phraseOndo.noun-preposition

description::
· noun-preposition--ondo-system is an-ondo-system of a-noun with a-preposition.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[He] _stxVrb:{saw} _stxObj:[storm clouds] _stxSpace:[(above) the bay].
_txtElln: _stxVrb:{ψαρεύει} _stxWith:[(με) καμάκι].

name::
* McsEngl.prepositional-phrase,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-preposition,

phraseOndo.noun-participle

description::
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[Much of our knowledge of Egyptian mathematics] _stxVrb:{comes} _stxDirection:[(from) [[the Rhind papyrus] [written by Ahmes some time before 1700B.C.]]].

name::
* McsEngl.noun-participle--system,
* McsEngl.participle-phrase-with-noun,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-participle,

phraseOndo.noun-conjuction--ondo-system

description::
· _stxEngl: ((the-color) of (the-car))
· _stxEngl: ((men) and (women))

name::
* McsEngl.conjunction--ondo-system,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-conjunction--ondo-system,

phraseOndo.noun-sentence

description::
· noun-sentence--ondo-system is an-ondo-system of a-noun with a-sentence.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[that] _stxVrb:{is} _stxSbjc:[[the tree] [I want]].
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[[the man] [who is buying a book]] _stxVrb:{is} _stxSbjc:[my uncle].

name::
* McsEngl.noun-sentence--system,
* McsEngl.phraseOndo.noun-sentence,

verb-argument of sentence

description::
· verb-argument of HmnmLago is a-logo-node that denotes a-VerbCnpt-argument.

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu!=verb-arument,
* McsEngl.argtVerb!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.logo-node.verb-argument!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-verb-argument!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.logo-verb-argument!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.modifier-of-verb!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.sentence'verb-argument!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.sentence/verb-argument!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.verb-argument!⇒VerbArgu,
* McsEngl.verb-modifier!⇒VerbArgu,

syntax of VerbArgu

description::
× McsHitp-creation: {2025-01-21},

· syntax is-expressed with:
* position,
* adjective, adverb,
* conjunction,

name::
* McsEngl.stxArgtVerb!⇒stxVerbArgu,
* McsEngl.stxVerbArgu!=syntax-of--verb-argument,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu'syntax!⇒stxVerbArgu,
* McsEngl.syntax.VerbArgu!⇒stxVerbArgu,

stxVerbArgu.position

description::
× McsHitp-creation: {2025-01-21},

· the-position of HmnmArgo denotes the-type of argument: subject, object.

· _stxEngl: I closed the door :: _stxSbj:[I] _stxVrb:{closed} _stxObj:[the door]

name::
* McsEngl.stxVerbArgu.position,

stxVerbArgu.adjective-adverb

description::
× McsHitp-creation: {2025-01-21},

· a-subject-complement is-denoted with an-adjective:
· _stxEngl: he is good :: _stxSbj:[he] _stxVrb:{is} _stxSbjc:[good].

· an-other-argument could-be-denoted with an-adverb:
· _stxEngl: she smiled happily. :: _stxSbj:[she] _stxVrb:{smiled} _stxManner:[happily].

name::
* McsEngl.stxVerbArgu.adjective-adverb,

stxVerbArgu.conjunction

description::
× McsHitp-creation: {2025-01-21},

·
· _stxZhon: 飞 得 快 :: _stxVrb:{飞} _stxManner:[(得)[快]]. fēi de kuài. != fly quickly.

· _stxZhon: 她 开心 地 笑 了。:: _stxSbj:[她] _stxManner:[开心 (地)] _stxVrb:{笑 了}。 != she smiled happily

name::
* McsEngl.stxVerbArgu.conjunction,

VerbArgu.SPECIFIC of HmnmLogoView

description::
===
* doing-VerbArgu,
* relation-VerbArgu,
=== specifics-division.logo-node
* argo-VerbArgu,
** noun-main--VerbArgu,
** noun-case--VerbArgu,
** adjective-VerbArgu,
** adverb-VerbArgu,
* argo-phrase--VerbArgu,
* conjunction-phrase--VerbArgu,
* infinitive-phrase--VerbArgu,
* sentence-VerbArgu,

=== specifics-division.nodeLago-denoted
* subject-VerbArgu,
* subject-target--VerbArgu,
* subject-complement--VerbArgu,
* object-VerbArgu,
* idirect-object--VerbArgu,
===
* subject-other--VerbArgu,
* absence-VerbArgu,
* cause-VerbArgu,
* degree(= quantity.relative)-VerbArgu,
* doer-VerbArgu,
* effect-VerbArgu,
* exception-VerbArgu,
* frequency-VerbArgu,
* goal-VerbArgu,
* instrument-VerbArgu,
* manner-VerbArgu,
* output-VerbArgu,
* quantity-VerbArgu,
* timePoint-VerbArgu,
* timeInterval-VerbArgu,
* space-VerbArgu,
* space-direction-VerbArgu,
* speed-VerbArgu,
===

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.specific,

VerbArgu.doing of HmnmLogoView

description::
· object is the-subject-target of a-doing-verb.

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.doing,

VerbArgu.relation of HmnmLogoView

description::
· subject-complement is the-subject-target of a-relation-verb.

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.relation,

VerbArgu.argo of HmnmLogoView

description::
* noun-main--VerbArgu,
* noun-case--VerbArgu,
* adjective-VerbArgu,
* adverb-VerbArgu,
===
· argo--verb-arg is a-verb-arg which is an-HmnmArgo.
* main-noun:
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[Cars] _stxVrb:{have} _stxSbjc:[wheels].
* adjective:
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[every person] _stxVrb:{is} _stxSbjc:[mortal].
* adverb:
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[I] _stxVrb:{work} _stxManner:[hard].
* pronoun:
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[She] _stxVrb:{works} _stxManner:[hard].

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.argo,
* McsEngl.argo-VerbArgu,

VerbArgu.conjunction-phrase of HmnmLogoView

description::
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[My brother the research associate] _stxVrb:{works} _stxSpace:[(at) a large polling firm]).

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.conjunction-system,
* McsEngl.conjunction-phrase--verb-argument,
* McsEngl.conjunction-system--VerbArgu,

VerbArgu.noun-phrase of HmnmLogoView

description::
· argo-system--verb-arg is a-verb-arg which is an-argo-system.
· _stxEngl: _sxtSbj:[cars] _stxVrb:{are} _stxSbjc:[dangerous machines].
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[Our teacher, Professor Lamanna,] _stxVrb:{loves} _stxObj:[grammar].
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[Jane's good friend FROM Boston] _stxVrb:{met} _stxObj:[Paul].
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[They] _stxVrb:{lived} _stxSpace:[(in) Canada] _stxTime:[(during) the war].
· _stxEngl: _sxtSbj:[the man [who is bying a book]] _sxtVrb:(is) _sxtSbjc:[my uncle].

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.noun-system,
* McsEngl.noun-system--VerbArgu,

VerbArgu.sentence of HmnmLogoView

description::
· sentence--verb-arg is a-verb-arg which is a-sentence.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[The senator] _stxVerb:(ran) _stxCause:[to catch the bus].

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.sentence,
* McsEngl.sentence-VerbArgu,

subject.English

description::
· English ALWAYS has subjects in its sentences.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[There] _stxVrb:{are} _stxSbjc:[beautiful beaches] _stxSpace:[(near) Santiago].
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[It] _stxVrb:{is rainning}.
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[There] _stxVrb:{exists} _stxSbjc:[a neural network that does not make avoidable mistakes]

name::
* McsEngl.subjEngl,
* McsEngl.subject.English!⇒subjEngl,

VerbArgu.subject-target of HmnmLogoView

description::
· subject-target is a-verb-argument that denotes a-semo-subject-target.

name::
* McsEngl.stxSbjt,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.02_secondary!⇒subtHmnm,

====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.υποκειμένου-στόχος!=subtHmnm,

specific::
* object--verb-arg,
* indirect-object--verb-arg,
* subject-complement--verb-arg,
* theme--verb-arg,
* patient--verb-arg,

subtHmnm.theme of HmnmLogoView

description::
· theme--verb-argument is the-verb-arg of a-stative-verb that is-(mainly)-related with the-subject.
===
"When used to mean different things, "patient" describes a receiver that changes state ("I crushed the car") and "theme" describes something that does not change state ("I have the car").[3] By that definition, stative verbs act on themes, and dynamic verbs act on patients."
[{2019-12-11} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_(grammar)]

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.theme,
* McsEngl.subject-target.theme,
* McsEngl.theme--verb-argument,

subtHmnm.patient of HmnmLogoView

description::
· patient--verb-argument is the-verb-arg of a-dynamic-verb that is-(mainly)-related with the-subject.
===
"When used to mean different things, "patient" describes a receiver that changes state ("I crushed the car") and "theme" describes something that does not change state ("I have the car").[3] By that definition, stative verbs act on themes, and dynamic verbs act on patients."
[{2019-12-11} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_(grammar)]

name::
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.patient,
* McsEngl.patient--verb-argument,
* McsEngl.subject-target.patient,

subtHmnm.subject-complement of HmnmLogoView

description::
· subject-complement is the-subject-target of relation-verbs.
[hmnSngo.{2023-06-01}]
===
· unfortunately there is NO DEFINITION for all the-languages and in one language on logo-subject-complement.
· the-verbs "be" and "become" connect subject-complements in all languages.
· also in some languages, if the-(main)-verb-arg which is-related to subject is adjective, then it is subject-complement.

name::
* McsEngl.stxSbjc!=subject-complement--syntax,
* McsEngl.syntax.subject-complement,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.subject-complement!⇒sbjcHmnm,
* McsEngl.VerbArguSubject-complement!⇒sbjcHmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'subject-complement!⇒sbjcHmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-subject-complement!⇒sbjcHmnm,
* McsEngl.logo-subject-complement--of-HmnmLago!⇒sbjcHmnm,
* McsEngl.rlnSubject-complement'syntax!⇒stxSbjc,
* McsEngl.subject-complement-of-HmnmLogoView!⇒sbjcHmnm,
* McsEngl.sbjcHmnm!=subject-complement,

linking-verb of subject-complement

description::
· linking-verb is the-verb that connects a-subject with its subject-complement.
· this is not a-definition, because we do-not-have a-definition for the-subject-complement.

name::
* McsEngl.copula,
* McsEngl.linking-verb,
* McsEngl.verb.linking,
====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.συνδετικό-ρήμα!-linking-verb,

info-resource of subject-complement

description::
* {2010-10-18} https://www.beatthegmat.com/linking-verbs-vs-state-verbs-mgmat-srategy-guide-t68656.html,
* {2017-09-16} https://ell.stackexchange.com/questions/142266/what-is-the-real-difference-between-stative-and-linking-verbs,

name::
* McsEngl.sbjcHmnm'Infrsc,

description::

sbjcHmnm.sentence

description::

name::
* McsEngl.sbjcHmnm.sentence,

subtHmnm.object of HmnmLogoView

description::
· logo-object is a-subject-target that is NOT subject-complement.
· if there are two subject-targets, the-first is the-object or the-one which is the-answer of 'what'.
· many languages DENOTE it, by placing it after the-verb.
· Chinese denotes it and with the-conjunction bǎ-把.

name::
* McsEngl.stxObj,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.object!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.VerbArguObject!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'object!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-object!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.logo-direct-object--of-HmnmLago!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.logo-object--of-HmnmLago!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.rlnObject'syntax!⇒stxObj,
* McsEngl.object-of-verb!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.objectHmn!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.objectLogHmn!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.objtHmnm!⇒objeHmnm,
* McsEngl.syntax.object,

subtHmnm.indirect-object of HmnmLogoView

description::
· logo-indirect-object is the-second subject-target or the-one which is NOT the-answer of 'what', if exists.

· _stxEngl: He gave _stxObj2:[me] a-book.
· _stxEngl: He gave a-book _stxObj2:[(to) me].

· _stxElln: _stxObj2:[μου] έδωσε ένα βιβλίο.
· _stxElln: έδωσε ένα βιβλίο _stxObj2:[(σε) μένα].

name::
* McsEngl.stxObj2,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.indirect-object!⇒obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.VerbArguIndirect-object!⇒obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.indirect-object--of-HmnmLago!⇒obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'indirect-object!⇒obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-indirect-object!⇒obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.logo-indirect-object--of-HmnmLago!⇒obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.rlnObject2'syntax!⇒stxObj2,
* McsEngl.obj2Hmnm,
* McsEngl.syntax.object2,

addressWpg::
* https://www.grammar-monster.com/glossary/indirect_object.htm,

VerbArgu.subject-other of HmnmLogoView

description::
· subject-other-VerbArgu is a-verb-argument that denotes a-semo-other-verb-arg.
===
"Οι επιρρηματικοί προσδιορισμοί προσδιορίζουν κυρίως ρήματα και δευτερευόντως άλλα μέρη του λόγου, όπως επιρρήματα, ονόματα και αντωνυμίες. Είναι μονολεκτικοί ή περιφραστικοί ως προς τη μορφή τους και εκφράζουν ποικίλες επιρρηματικές σχέσεις, όπως τόπο, χρόνο, ποσό, τρόπο, μέσο ή όργανο, συνοδεία, αιτία, σκοπό, αναφορά, αποτέλεσμα, εναντίωση ή παραχώρηση, προϋπόθεση ή όρο κ.ά.:"
[{2021-07-27 retrieved} http://ebooks.edu.gr/ebooks/v/html/8547/2326/Syntaktiko-Archaias-Ellinikis-Glossas_A-B-G-Gymnasiou_html-apli/index_01_13_0.html]

name::
* McsEngl.stxOther,
* _stxSbjo,
* McsEngl.adverbial,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.03_other,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.subject-other,
* McsEngl.VerbArgu.other,

VerbArgu.time of HmnmLogoView

description::
× senso-mind-relation: time-argument--of-doing,
· time--verb-arg\a\ is a-verb-arg that denotes a-semo-when.
· languages use adverbs of time or conjunctions to express it\a\.

* adverb:
· _stxEngl: _stxTime:[Today] _stxSbj:[she] _stxVrb:{wore} her hair down around her shoulders. [HarperCollins]

* conjunction:
· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:I _stxVrb:start _stxTime:(at) eight (in) the morning. [WordNet]

* question:
· _stxEngl: _stxTime:[when] _stxVrb:{will _stxSbj:[he] return}? ==> _stxSbj:[he] _stxVrb:{wil return} _stxTime:[x].

sentence of HmnmLogoView

description::
· sentence of HmnmLago is a-logo-node that denotes a-semo-sentence (it denotes a-process-or-relation in time of an-entity).
· sentences are the-term units of logo-views.
"Αλλά γιατί η πρόταση, και όχι η λέξη ή η φράση, έχει τον «πρώτο λόγο» στον διάλογο, στη γλωσσική επικοινωνία; Γιατί η πρόταση εκφράζει μια ολοκληρωμένη σκέψη. Κάντε τη σύγκριση ανάμεσα στην πρόταση Το παιδί έφυγε, τη φράση το παιδί και τη λέξη παιδί. Είναι εύκολο να καταλάβει κανείς ότι η φράση και η λέξη εκφράζουν «μισές», ανολοκλήρωτες σκέψεις. Μόνο η πρόταση εκφράζει μια ολοκληρωμένη σκέψη. Κι αυτό γιατί, ενώ η φράση το παιδί και η λέξη παιδί απλά ονομάζουν κάτι, στην πρόταση ονομάζεται κάτι και, επιπλέον, λέγεται κάτι γι' αυτό. Σε αυτό βρίσκεται η πληρότητα της πρότασης."
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=78]
"Η λέξη πρόταση βγαίνει από το ρήμα προτείνω που, στα αρχαία ελληνικά, σήμαινε 'τεντώνω προς, τεντώνω μπροστά'. Είναι η εικόνα του τοξότη που τεντώνει τη χορδή του τόξου για να εξαπολύσει το βέλος. Η γλωσσική επικοινωνία γίνεται με προτάσεις, δηλαδή με γλωσσικές «κατασκευές» που τις «εξαπολύουμε», σαν βέλη, στον συνομιλητή μας, τις «προτείνουμε»."
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=77]

====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.πρόταση!η!=sentence,

part of sentence

description::
* verb,
* verb-argument,
===
* subject,
* predicate,

name::
* McsEngl.sentence'part,
* McsEngl.sentence/part,

verb (link) of sentence

verb-argument (link) of sentence

predicate of sentence

description::
· predicate I call the-complement of the-subject.
[hmnSngo.{2023-05-12}]
"The term predicate is used in one of two ways in linguistics and its subfields. The first defines a predicate as everything in a standard declarative sentence except the subject, and the other views it as just the main content verb or associated predicative expression of a clause. Thus, by the first definition the predicate of the sentence Frank likes cake is likes cake. By the second definition, the predicate of the same sentence is just the content verb likes, whereby Frank and cake are the arguments of this predicate. Differences between these two definitions can lead to confusion.[1]"
[{2023-05-11 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predicate_(grammar)]
===
"Αυτό το οποίο ονομάζεται είναι το όνομα ή υποκείμενο της πρότασης (υποκείμενο σημαίνει «θέμα», αυτό για το οποίο γίνεται λόγος), και αυτό το οποίο λέγεται γι' αυτό που ονομάζεται (το όνομα, το υποκείμενο) είναι το κατηγόρημα. Η λέξη κατηγόρημα προέρχεται από το αρχαίο ελληνικό ρήμα κατηγορώ, που σημαίνει 'λέω κάτι για κάποιον ή για κάτι'. Τη λέξη τη χρησιμοποιούμε και σήμερα, κατηγορία (π.χ. στη γλώσσα των δικαστηρίων), και σημαίνει 'κάτι που λέω εναντίον κάποιου'.
Αυτό λοιπόν που κάνει την πρόταση να είναι η βασική δομή της αρχιτεκτονικής της γλώσσας, της κάθε γλώσσας, είναι ότι εκφράζει μια ολοκληρωμένη σκέψη, καθώς δεν ονομάζει απλά κάτι αλλά λέει κάτι γι' αυτό και έτσι το προσδιορίζει."
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=79]

name::
* McsEngl.predicate/pridikéit/-of-sentence,
* McsEngl.sentence/predicate,
====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.κατηγόρημα-το/katiyórima-to/!=sentence/predicate, (members)

phrase of sentence

description::
· phrase I call a-part of a-sentence with more than names.
· similar expressions/a/, can-be phrases or compound-names, depending on the-existance or not of a-concept/b/ with this/a/ expression as name of it/b/.
[hmnSngo.{2023-05-12}]
===
· phrase I call a-part of a-sentence with more than one part-of-speech.
[hmnSngo.{2022-11-13}]

name::
* McsEngl.phrase,
* McsEngl.sentence'phrase,
====== langoGreek:
* McsElln.φράση!η!=phrase,

descriptionLong::
"A phrase is a group of words that convey a particular meaning, but do not form a complete sentence. Phrases can be used to modify a noun or verb, provide additional information or emphasis, or serve as a subject or object in a sentence. Examples of common phrases include "in the meantime," "on the other hand," "according to," "in order to," and "as soon as possible.""
[{2023-05-11 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/]
===
"In grammar, a phrase—called expression in some contexts—is a group of words or singular word acting as a grammatical unit. For instance, the English expression "the very happy squirrel" is a noun phrase which contains the adjective phrase "very happy". Phrases can consist of a single word or a complete sentence. In theoretical linguistics, phrases are often analyzed as units of syntactic structure such as a constituent."
[{2023-05-11 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phrase]

phrase.SPECIFIC

description::
* conjunction-phrase,
* argo-phrase,
* verb-phrase,

name::
* McsEngl.phrase.specific,

phrase.verb

description::
· verb-phrase is a-phrase with a-verb which is also a-verb-argument.

name::
* McsEngl.phrase.verb!⇒phraseVerb,
* McsEngl.phraseVerb,
* McsEngl.verb-phrase!⇒phraseVerb,

specific-tree-of-phraseVerb::
* infinitive-phraseVerb,
* participle-phraseVerb,

phraseVerb.infinitive

description::
"The grammatical structure of the sentence "Children like to wear new clothes" is as follows:
Subject: Children
Verb: like
Object: to wear new clothes
The verb "like" is followed by the infinitive phrase "to wear new clothes," which serves as the object of the sentence. The infinitive phrase "to wear" acts as the base form of the verb, and "new clothes" functions as the direct object of the verb "wear." Overall, the sentence follows a subject-verb-object (SVO) structure."
[{2023-05-28 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/]

name::
* McsEngl.infinitive-phrase,
* McsEngl.phrase.infinitive,
* McsEngl.phraseVerb.infinitive,

description::

· _stxEngl: _stxSbj:[She] _stxVrb:{looked} _stxDirection:[(at) the papers] _stxSpace:[(around) her]. [HarperCollins]

* McsEngl.syntax.sentence,

word-order of sentence

description::
"In linguistics, word order (also known as linear order) is the order of the syntactic constituents of a language. Word order typology studies it from a cross-linguistic perspective, and examines how different languages employ different orders. Correlations between orders found in different syntactic sub-domains are also of interest. The primary word orders that are of interest are
* the constituent order of a clause, namely the relative order of subject, object, and verb;
* the order of modifiers (adjectives, numerals, demonstratives, possessives, and adjuncts) in a noun phrase;
* the order of adverbials."
[{2023-05-05 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_order]

name::
* McsEngl.sentence'word-order,
* McsEngl.word-order-of-sentence,

sentenceAsk.time

description::
· we ask time.

· _stxEngl: WHEN was the first successful heart transplant performed?

· _stxElln: ΠΟΤΕ πήγες στο βουνό;

· _stxZhon: 你 什么时候 来？ :: _stxSbj:[Nǐ] _stxTime:[shénme shíhou] _stxVrb:{lái}? When are you coming?

name::
* McsEngl.time-sentenceAsk,
* McsEngl.sentenceAsk.time,

sentenceAsk.question-word

description::
"Here are some examples of questions using question words:
1. **What** is the population of Tokyo?
2. **Where** is the nearest galaxy to the Milky Way?
3. **When** was the first successful heart transplant performed?
4. **Why** do leaves change color in the fall?
5. **How** does photosynthesis work?
6. **Who** invented the telephone?
7. **Which** planet in our solar system is known as the Red Planet?
8. **Whose** theory of relativity fundamentally changed our understanding of space and time?
These question words help in structuring inquiries to seek specific types of information."
[{2024-11-04 retrieved} https://x.com/i/grok]

name::
* McsEngl.question-word-sentenceAsk,
* McsEngl.sentenceAsk.question-word,

sentencePolysemous.semantic

description::
"in semantic ambiguity the structure remains the same, but the individual words are interpreted differently."
[{2023-09-18 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntactic_ambiguity#Syntactic_and_semantic_ambiguity]

name::
* McsEngl.semantic-ambiguity-of-sentence,
* McsEngl.sentencePolysemous.semantic,

sentencePolysemous.syntactic

description::
"Syntactic ambiguity, also called structural ambiguity,[1] amphiboly or amphibology, is a situation where a sentence may be interpreted in more than one way due to ambiguous sentence structure.
Syntactic ambiguity does not come from the range of meanings of single words, but from the relationship between the words and clauses of a sentence, and the sentence structure hidden behind the word order. In other words, a sentence is syntactically ambiguous when a reader or listener can reasonably interpret one sentence as having multiple possible structures.
In law cases, courts may be asked to interpret the meaning of such ambiguities in laws or contracts. In some instances, arguments claiming highly unlikely interpretations have been called frivolous.[citation needed] A set of possible parse trees for an ambiguous sentence is called a parse forest.[2][3] The process of resolving syntactic ambiguity is called syntactic disambiguation.[4]"
[{2023-09-18 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntactic_ambiguity]

name::
* McsEngl.amphiboly,
* McsEngl.sentencePolysemous.syntactic,
* McsEngl.structural-ambiguity-of-sentence,
* McsEngl.syntactic-ambiguity-of-sentence,

· in other words, a-semo-sentence that does-not-denote brain-info.

"Rules describe the general association of causes with effects ('laws'), situations with actions ('triggers'), premises with conclusions ('implications'), and so are used to represent: physical, chemical, and biological processes; medical guidelines; business and legal policies; conditional equations, preferences, and probabilities; statistical correlations; grammars; transition functions; logics; database views; as well as declarative (functional, logic, and functional-logic) programs."

=== qǐng-请:
· _stxZhon: 请 坐。 Qǐng zuò. != Please sit down.
· _stxZhon: 你 可 不 可以 …… ？ Nǐ kě bu kěyǐ…? Could you...?

sentence.suggestion

description::
· (n) suggestion (an idea that is suggested) "the picnic was her suggestion"
[{2023-07-20 retrieved} http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn]

1. Past Modal Verbs: (Would, Could, Should,)
I think we should increase the price.
I would suggest increasing the price.
I would recommend increasing the price.
The best course of action would probably be to increase the price.
We should probably consider increasing the price.
We could increase the price.

2. Perhaps / Maybe
Perhaps we should hire somebody for this role.
Perhaps we could outsource a company for this project.
Maybe we should increase the price.

3. Let’s
Let’s put the prices up.
Let’s create a survey.

4. Just
It’s just an idea, but we could look at reviewing the recruitment process.
It’s just a suggestion, but we could only use social media for this campaign.

5. Suggest(ion) / Recommend(ation)
My suggestion would be to hire somebody else for this role.
I suggest hiring somebody else for this position.
My recommendation would be to promote John.
I recommend promoting John.

Make Suggestions with Questions
6. How about…? / What about…?
How about dividing this task between two people?
What about trying something completely different?
What about asking David his opinion?

7. Shall…?
Shall we start by trying to understand the root cause?
Shall I visit a couple of our stores to try and understand what’s going on?

8. What if…?
What if we start by trying to understand the root cause?
What if I visit a couple of our stores to try and understand what’s going on?

9. Why don’t …?
Why don’t you talk to your boss about this?
Why don’t we invest more of the budget in training and development?

10. Other Common Questions to Make Suggestions
May I suggest…?
Would you consider…?
Wouldn’t it be better to…?
Shouldn’t you…?
Why don’t you…?
Have you tried…?
Have you thought about…?
[{2023-07-20 retrieved} https://impactfulenglish.com/make-suggestions-business-meetings/]

=== jiànyì-建议!=sentenceSuggestion:
· _stxZhon: 你的建议很聪明。 :: Nǐ de jiànyì hěn cōngming. != Your suggestion is very clever.

=== yàobù..ba-要不..吧!~VerbauxZhon!=sentenceSuggestion:
· _stxZhon: 大家 都 有点 累 了，要不 休息 一会儿 吧 。 :: _stxQuantity:[Dàjiā dōu] _stxQuantity:[yǒudiǎn] _stxVrb:{lèi le}, _stxVrb:{yàobù xiūxi} _stxTime:[yīhuìr] {ba}. != Everyone is a little tired. Let's rest for a while.

addressWpg::
* Τέχνη Γραμματική, Διονύσιος ο Θραξ, https://el.wikisource.org/wiki/Τέχνη_Γραμματική,
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Art_of_Grammar,

grammar'relation-to-language

description::
"grammar vs language
Language is a system of communication used by humans to convey meaning. It consists of a set of rules for combining words into sentences and using those sentences to communicate ideas. Grammar is the set of rules that govern the structure of a language. It includes rules for word order, word formation, and word meaning.
In other words, language is the overall system of communication, while grammar is the specific set of rules that govern how that language is used. Language is made up of words, while grammar is made up of the rules for how those words can be combined to form sentences.
Here is a simple analogy: language is like a set of LEGO bricks, while grammar is like the instructions for building things with those bricks. You can't build anything with LEGO bricks without following the instructions, but you can also build many different things with the same set of bricks. In the same way, you can't communicate effectively without following the rules of grammar, but you can communicate many different things using the same language.
Here are some examples of the difference between language and grammar:
* Language: English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese
* Grammar: The subject of a sentence must agree with the verb in number. Adjectives come before nouns. Prepositions take noun objects.
Language is constantly evolving, but grammar rules tend to change more slowly. This is because grammar rules are often based on the way that people have spoken and written a language for centuries.
Good grammar is important for effective communication. It helps to ensure that your sentences are clear, concise, and easy to understand. When you use correct grammar, your writing and speaking are more professional and credible.
However, it is important to remember that grammar is just one aspect of language. There are many other factors that contribute to effective communication, such as vocabulary, tone, and body language."
[{2023-09-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/d76495415eff1bbc]
===
"grammar vs language
Grammar and language are closely related concepts, but they refer to different aspects of communication and linguistics.
1. Language:
- Language is a broad and complex system of communication used by humans (and some animals) to convey meaning through the use of sounds, symbols, and gestures.
- It encompasses both spoken and written forms and varies significantly across different cultures and regions.
- Language is a fundamental aspect of human communication and plays a central role in conveying thoughts, emotions, information, and cultural aspects.
2. Grammar:
- Grammar is a subset of language and refers to the set of rules and structures that govern how words are organized into sentences and how those sentences convey meaning.
- It includes rules for word order, sentence structure, verb conjugation, tense, mood, voice, and other linguistic elements.
- Grammar provides the framework for constructing and interpreting meaningful expressions in a language.
- It is essential for ensuring clarity and effective communication in a language.
In summary, language is the broader concept encompassing all aspects of human communication, while grammar is a specific aspect of language that deals with the rules and structures governing how words are used to create meaningful sentences. Grammar is a crucial component of language, as it allows for the structured and coherent expression of ideas within a linguistic system."
[{2023-09-30 retrieved} ]

name::
* McsEngl.grammar'relation-to-language,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'relation-to-grammar,

tech of HmnmLago

description::
"Language technology, often called human language technology (HLT), studies methods of how computer programs or electronic devices can analyze, produce, modify or respond to human texts and speech.[1] Working with language technology often requires broad knowledge not only about linguistics but also about computer science. It consists of natural language processing (NLP) and computational linguistics (CL) on the one hand, many application oriented aspects of these, and more low-level aspects such as encoding and speech technology on the other hand.
Note that these elementary aspects are normally not considered to be within the scope of related terms such as natural language processing and (applied) computational linguistics, which are otherwise near-synonyms. As an example, for many of the world's lesser known languages, the foundation of language technology is providing communities with fonts and keyboard setups so their languages can be written on computers or mobile devices.[2]"
[{2023-08-24 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_technology]

name::
* McsEngl.HLT!=human-language-tech!⇒techLHmnm,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'tech!⇒techLHmnm,
* McsEngl.techLHmnm,
* McsEngl.techLHmnm!=human-mind-language-tech,

techLHmnm.computational-linguistics (link)

techLHmnm.natural-language-processing (link)

info-resource of HmnmLago

addressWpg::
* Joan Bybee eds(1994) The Evolution of grammar: https://www.academia.edu/4975503/Joan_Bybee_eds_1994_The_Evolution_of_grammar?email_work_card=view-paper,
* https://www.sil.org/resources/glossaries-linguistic-terms,
* https://medium.com/s/story/the-internet-is-helping-save-forgotten-languages-dcc308509feb,

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'Infrsc,

corpus of HmnmLago

description::
· text of speech of this language.

"A text corpus is a collection of written or spoken texts used for linguistic analysis, natural language processing, or various other language-related research and applications. Text corpora can be categorized based on the languages they contain. Here are some common examples of text corpora for various languages:

1. **English Corpora:**
- **Brown Corpus:** A widely used corpus of American English, containing a variety of text genres.
- **Corpus of Contemporary American English (COCA):** A large corpus of contemporary American English.
- **British National Corpus (BNC):** A corpus of British English from the late 20th century.
- **Penn Treebank:** A corpus of American English used for parsing and part-of-speech tagging.

2. **Spanish Corpora:**
- **Corpus del Español:** A large corpus of Spanish text from various sources.
- **Cervantes Corpus:** Contains Spanish texts from the works of Miguel de Cervantes.

3. **French Corpora:**
- **Frantext:** A corpus of French literary texts.
- **Le Monde Diplomatique Corpus:** A corpus of French political texts.

4. **German Corpora:**
- **Deutsches Textarchiv:** A corpus of German texts from various sources.
- **Grimm Corpus:** Texts from the Grimm Brothers' fairy tales.

5. **Chinese Corpora:**
- **Chinese Gigaword:** A corpus of Chinese news text.
- **Peking University Corpus of Modern Chinese (PKU):** A widely used corpus for Chinese natural language processing.

6. **Japanese Corpora:**
- **Kyoto University Text Corpus:** A collection of Japanese texts for linguistic research.
- **Aozora Bunko:** A digital library of Japanese literature.

7. **Arabic Corpora:**
- **Buckwalter Arabic Morphological Analyzer:** A corpus of Arabic text used for morphological analysis.
- **Quranic Arabic Corpus:** Focuses on the analysis of the Quranic Arabic language.

8. **Russian Corpora:**
- **Russian National Corpus (RNC):** A comprehensive corpus of the Russian language.
- **SynTagRus:** A Russian dependency treebank.

9. **Other Languages:**
- There are many other corpora for languages around the world, including Portuguese, Italian, Dutch, and more.

These are just a few examples of text corpora available for different languages. Linguists, researchers, and natural language processing practitioners often rely on these corpora to study language patterns, build language models, and develop language-related technologies."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/4b82ae99-5b39-4e62-ac83-ff24a12e1487]

name::
* McsEngl.corpus-of-HmnmLago,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'corpus,
* McsEngl.text-corpus-of-HmnmLago,

07_linguistics (link) of HmnmLago

knower.native of HmnmLago

description::
"An article titled “The Native Speaker: An Achievable Model?” published by the Asian EFL Journal[14] states that there are six general principles that relate to the definition of "native speaker". The principles, according to the study, are typically accepted by language experts across the scientific field. A native speaker is defined according to the following guidelines:
1) The individual acquired the language in early childhood.
1) The individual has intuitive knowledge of the language.
1) The individual is able to produce fluent, spontaneous discourse.
1) The individual is competent in communication.
1) The individual identifies with or is identified by a language community.
1) The individual has a dialect accent (including the official dialect)."
[{2019-08-14} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_language]

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago-knower.native,
* McsEngl.native-knower--of-HmnmLago,

paralanguage of HmnmLago

description::
"Paralanguage refers to the non-verbal elements of communication used to modify meaning and convey emotion. Paralanguage may be expressed consciously or unconsciously, and it includes the pitch, volume, and, in some cases, intonation of speech. Sometimes the definition is restricted to vocally-produced sounds. The study of paralanguage is known as paralinguistics".
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paralanguage]

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'paralanguage,

European-Day-of-Languages-26-September of HmnmLago

description::
· "The European Day of Languages is observed 26 September, as proclaimed by the Council of Europe on 6 December 2001, at the end of the European Year of Languages (2001), which had been jointly organised by the Council of Europe and the European Union.[1] Its aim is to encourage language learning across Europe."
[{2023-05-30 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Day_of_Languages]

International-Mother-Language-Day-21-February of HmnmLago

description::
· "International Mother Language Day, Bengali: আন্তর্জাতিক মাতৃভাষা দিবস, is a worldwide annual observance held on 21 February to promote awareness of linguistic and cultural diversity and to promote multilingualism. First announced by UNESCO on 17 November 1999,[1] it was formally recognized by the United Nations General Assembly with the adoption of UN resolution 56/262[2] in 2002. Mother Language Day is part of a broader initiative "to promote the preservation and protection of all languages used by peoples of the world" as adopted by the UN General Assembly on 16 May 2007 in UN resolution 61/266,[3] which also established 2008 as the International Year of Languages.[4][5][6][7] The idea to celebrate International Mother Language Day was the initiative of Bangladesh i.e. Bengali Country. In Bangladesh, 21 February (1952) is the anniversary of the day when the Bengalis i.e. Pakistani Bengali Muslims (now Bangladeshi Bengali Muslims) of the Pakistani province of East Bengal (now independent state of Bangladesh) fought for recognition of their Bengali language.[8] It is also observed by the Bengalis i.e. Indian Bengali Hindus of the Indian states of West Bengal, Assam, Jharkhand and Tripura."
[{2023-05-30 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Mother_Language_Day]

name::
* McsEngl.International-Mother-Language-Day-21-February,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'International-Mother-Language-Day-21-February,

mutual-intelligibility of HmnmLago

description::
× McsHitp-creation: {2025-04-07},
"Okay, let's break down the concept of **mutually intelligible languages**.

**What is Mutual Intelligibility?**
Mutual intelligibility is a relationship between languages or dialects in which speakers of different but related varieties can readily understand each other without prior study or special effort.
Key points to understand:
1. **It's a Spectrum:** It's not always a simple yes/no situation. Intelligibility can range from almost complete understanding to only partial comprehension.
2. **Asymmetry:** It's common for intelligibility to be asymmetric. Speakers of language A might understand language B better than speakers of language B understand language A. This can happen due to differences in phonology (one language having simpler sounds), grammar, or levels of exposure (speakers of a smaller language might be more exposed to a larger, related one).
3. **Linguistic vs. Political:** Mutual intelligibility is primarily a *linguistic* concept. Whether two mutually intelligible varieties are classified as "dialects" of one language or as separate "languages" often depends heavily on political, social, and historical factors, rather than purely linguistic distance.
4. **Context Matters:** Understanding can depend on the topic (simple daily conversation vs. technical discussion), the specific dialects being used (standard vs. regional), and the individual speakers' background and motivation.

**Examples of Mutually Intelligible Languages/Groups:**
Here are some well-known examples, often grouped by language family:
* **North Germanic (Scandinavian):**
* **Danish, Norwegian (Bokmål & Nynorsk), Swedish:** This is a classic example. Written Danish and Norwegian Bokmål are very similar. Spoken Danish can be harder for Swedes and Norwegians due to its pronunciation. Norwegians often understand both Danes and Swedes relatively well. (Icelandic and Faroese are also North Germanic but are *not* mutually intelligible with the mainland Scandinavian languages).
* **West South Slavic:**
* **Bosnian, Croatian, Montenegrin, Serbian (BCMS):** These languages are based on the same dialect (Shtokavian) and have extremely high mutual intelligibility, especially in their standard forms. They function linguistically as a single pluricentric language, though they are treated as distinct languages for political and cultural reasons, with differences primarily in vocabulary and some minor grammatical points.
* **East South Slavic:**
* **Bulgarian and Macedonian:** These languages are very closely related and share a high degree of mutual intelligibility, especially in border regions. Like BCMS, their status as distinct languages vs. dialects of one language is politically sensitive but linguistically they are structurally very similar (both having lost noun cases and developed definite articles, unlike most other Slavic languages).
* **West Slavic:**
* **Czech and Slovak:** Extremely high mutual intelligibility, particularly among older generations who grew up with Czechoslovakia. It remains very high today, though perhaps slightly decreasing among younger people with less cross-exposure.
* **East Slavic:**
* **Russian, Ukrainian, Belarusian:** There is significant mutual intelligibility within this group, but it's complex and often asymmetric. Ukrainian and Belarusian are generally closer to each other than either is to Russian. Many Ukrainians and Belarusians understand Russian well (due to historical exposure), while native Russian speakers might find understanding spoken Ukrainian or Belarusian more challenging without familiarity.
* **Romance Languages:**
* **Spanish and Portuguese:** Significant mutual intelligibility, especially in written form. Portuguese speakers often understand Spanish better than vice versa, partly due to Portuguese having a more complex vowel system. Galician (spoken in Spain) is very close to Portuguese and acts as a bridge.
* **Spanish and Italian:** Partial mutual intelligibility. Many cognates exist, but differences in pronunciation and grammar can hinder easy conversation.
* **Other Romance Languages (Catalan, Occitan, French, Romanian):** Varying degrees of partial intelligibility exist between these languages, especially those geographically closer (e.g., Spanish/Catalan/Occitan/Italian).
* **West Germanic:**
* **Dutch and Afrikaans:** High mutual intelligibility, particularly written Afrikaans (which evolved from Dutch dialects). Spoken forms are generally understandable despite pronunciation differences.
* **German and Yiddish:** Yiddish originated as a High German dialect. There's considerable lexical overlap allowing some intelligibility, but significant differences in pronunciation, grammar, and vocabulary (due to Hebrew/Aramaic and Slavic influences in Yiddish) limit full understanding.
* **Dutch and Low German Dialects:** Some dialects of Low German are partially intelligible with Dutch.
* **Indo-Aryan:**
* **Hindi and Urdu:** Linguistically registers of the same language (Hindustani). Spoken forms used in daily life are highly mutually intelligible. Differences emerge in formal vocabulary (Hindi borrowing from Sanskrit, Urdu from Persian/Arabic) and especially in the writing systems (Devanagari for Hindi, Perso-Arabic script for Urdu).
* **Austronesian:**
* **Malay and Indonesian:** These are different standardized forms of the same Malay language. Mutual intelligibility is very high.
Mutual intelligibility is a fascinating aspect of how languages relate, often blurring the lines between what constitutes a "language" versus a "dialect"."
[{2025-04-07 retrieved} https://gemini.google.com/app/631df56ca29cbca0]

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'mutual-intelligibility,
* McsEngl.mutual-intelligibility--of-HmnmLago,

DOING of HmnmLago

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'doing,

* McsEngl.fctThinking.language-processing,

specific::

* evoluting,
* implementation,
* learning,
* translation,

main-functing of HmnmLago

description::
"... one general assumption about language, almost a dogma, philosophy and common understanding of linguistics and psychology is that language is primarily a means of communication and that it evolved as a means of communication, probably that's totally false. It seems that language evolved and is designed as a mode of creating and interpreting thought ..."
[{2020-07-29} Noam-Chomsky https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7aqNLEnHSyo]
"Roman Jakobson identified six functions of language, only one of which is the traditional system of reference.
* referential: conveys information about some real phenomenon
* expressive: describes feelings of the speaker
* conative: attempts to elicit some behavior from the addressee
* phatic: builds a relationship between both parties in a conversation
* metalingual: self-references
* poetic: focuses on the text independent of reference"
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatics]

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'function,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'main-functing,

* McsEngl.mapping-functing!=fctMindLogo,
* McsEngl.verb.map!~verbEnglA2!=fctMindLogo,

descriptionLong::
"3. Language processing: The brain allows us to understand and produce language, through a complex network of regions responsible for speech, comprehension, and grammar.
[{2023-04-20 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/]
===
The human brain has separate systems for processing WRITTEN and SPOKEN language, a new study suggests. The research, being described today in the journal Nature supports a growing body of evidence that the brain divides complex tasks into compartments and assigns specific functions to independent subsystems.
The phenomenon has been shown in tasks like vision, but this is the first time it has been demonstrated in language, according to Dr. Alfonso Caramazza, professor and director of cognitive science at the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore who wrote the new study.
[Blakeslee, {1991-02}, pB13]

evoluting of HmnmLago

description::
· we do-not-know, definitely, the-evolution of our language.
· for me, the-milestones in this evolution are:

· gestural-languages:
· changes in nature forced pre-humans to bipedalism.
· bipedalism freed hands.
· free hands gave rise to gestural-communication.
· gestural-languages is the-cause of "right-handiness" and the-expansion in human-brain size, because of the-increased quantity of concepts stored in the-brain.

· oral-languages:
· for millions of years gestures are-mixed with sounds.
· as the-quantity of sounds increased the-vocal-track gets an-L-shape.
· together with the-evolution of the-human-ear and the-hyoid-bone, humans were-able to produce and distiguish many sounds.
· as a-result spoken-languages became dominant.

· written-languages:
· about 5,000 years ago the-invention of textual-languages helped human-societies to store and transmit more easily the-acquired knowledge to next generations.

">timeline of human language:
Creating a timeline for the development of human language involves a mix of linguistic, archaeological, and genetic evidence. It's important to note that much of this timeline is speculative, as there is no direct evidence of when exactly our ancestors started speaking. Here's a broad overview:
1. **6-7 Million Years Ago**: Human lineage diverges from that of chimpanzees and bonobos, our closest living relatives.
2. **2-3 Million Years Ago**: The genus Homo evolves. Early hominins likely had a range of vocalizations, although not yet what we would recognize as language.
3. **500,000 - 200,000 Years Ago**: Homo sapiens' ancestors, such as Homo heidelbergensis or Homo erectus, might have had a form of proto-language. Their vocal tract anatomy begins to resemble modern humans.
4. **100,000 - 50,000 Years Ago**: Anatomically modern humans appear. The capacity for articulate speech likely existed, as evidenced by the anatomy of the vocal tract and the FOXP2 gene, known to be important for language.
5. **50,000 - 30,000 Years Ago**: The Upper Paleolithic Revolution. There's a significant advancement in tool technology, art, and culture, suggesting complex communication and possibly the development of fully-fledged language.
6. **10,000 Years Ago**: Agriculture begins, leading to more complex social structures and the need for more intricate language and communication.
7. **5,000 - 4,000 Years Ago**: The earliest known writing systems develop in Sumer (Mesopotamia) and Ancient Egypt.
8. **Classical Antiquity (8th Century BC - 5th Century AD)**: Early alphabets develop. Major languages like Latin, Ancient Greek, Sanskrit, and Classical Chinese become sophisticated, with extensive literature.
9. **Middle Ages (5th - 15th Century AD)**: Languages continue to evolve. Latin splits into the Romance languages. The printing press (15th Century) revolutionizes language dissemination.
10. **Modern Era (16th Century - Present)**: Global exploration and colonization spread European languages worldwide. The Industrial Revolution and technological advances in the 19th and 20th centuries further enhance communication.
11. **21st Century and Beyond**: The digital age brings about new forms of communication, global interconnectedness, and the evolution of internet-based language and communication styles.
This timeline is a general outline and should be taken as an approximation, given the many uncertainties and ongoing research in the field."
[{2023-12-20 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/9bb6d82d-0410-4b0b-9464-f1ef4b1482c0]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-HmnmLago,
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'evoluting,

{Bce1250}-HmnmLago-Chinese::
"The earliest examples of Chinese are divinatory inscriptions on oracle bones from around 1250 BCE in the late Shang dynasty."
[{2021-03-27} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language]
* McsEngl.{HmnmLago'Bce1250}-Chinese-written,

{Bce2800}-HmnmLago-syllabic::
"The earliest recorded syllables are on tablets written around 2800 BC in the Sumerian city of Ur. This shift from pictograms to syllables has been called "the most important advance in the history of writing"."
[{2019-08-19} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syllable]
* McsEngl.{Bce2800}-HmnmLago-syllabic,
* McsEngl.{HmnmLago'Bce2800}-syllabic,

{Bce3200}-HmnmLago-written-Egypt::
"Πριν το τέλος της 4ης χιλιετίας (γύρω στο 3200) π.Χ. θα εμφανιστεί η γραφή στην Αίγυπτο (ιερογλυφική γραφή· βλ. εικ. 12). Η ανάγκη που τη γέννησε ήταν, και εδώ, κοινωνική: η ενοποίηση της Αιγύπτου κάτω από έναν φαραώ (βασιλιά) και οι ανάγκες της διοίκησης. Επιπλέον, υπήρχαν και ειδικότερες ανάγκες που γεννιούνταν από μια ιδιαιτερότητα της Αιγύπτου - τις πλημμύρες του Νείλου. Οι ετήσιες αυτές πλημμύρες υποχρέωναν τους Αιγύπτιους να ξαναπροσδιορίζουν κάθε χρονιά τα όρια και τις εκτάσεις των χωραφιών που χάνονταν κάτω από το νερό. Η γραφή ήταν ένα απαραίτητο εργαλείο για μια τέτοια περίπλοκη δραστηριότητα. Κατά την αιγυπτιακή μυθολογία εφευρέτης της γραφής ήταν ο Θωθ, ο θεός της σοφίας."
[{2022-04-16 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=32]
* McsEngl.{Bce3200}-HmnmLago-written-Egypt,
* McsEngl.{HmnmLago'Bce3200}-written-Egypt,

{Bce4000}-HmnmLago-written-Mesopotamia::
"Η γραφή πρωτοεμφανίζεται γύρω στο 4000 με 3000 π.Χ. στη Μεσοποταμία (το σημερινό Ιράκ), στην περιοχή ακριβώς όπου διαδραματίζονται οι μύθοι που συζητήσαμε λίγο πριν. Στη Μεσοποταμία λοιπόν δημιουργείται για πρώτη φορά ένα σύστημα από σημεία, που επιχειρεί να καταγράψει τον λόγο, να δώσει στα «φτερωτά λόγια» μονιμότητα, διάρκεια πέρα από τη στιγμή που λέγεται κάτι."
[{2022-04-16 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=32]
* McsEngl.{iK1.BceK1x004}-HmnmLago-written-Mesopotamia,
* McsEngl.{HmnmLago'iK1.BceK1x004}-written-Mesopotamia,

{Bp2'000'000}-HmnmLago::
"Ο παλαιολιθικός, λοιπόν, άνθρωπος του 2.000.000 π.Χ. έχει αρχίσει να σκέφτεται τον κόσμο με τον ίδιο τρόπο που λειτουργεί η γλώσσα και τα νοήματά της: γενικά και όχι καθηλωμένα στο συγκεκριμένο ερέθισμα, στην άμεση εμπειρία. Γι' αυτό έχουμε κάθε λόγο να πιστεύουμε ότι, από τη στιγμή που εμφανίζονται τα πρώτα εργαλεία, υπάρχει και η γλώσσα. Εργαλεία και γλώσσα βασίζονται στις ίδιες νοητικές ικανότητες."
[{2022-04-16 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=34]
* McsEngl.{iK2.BpK2x002}-HmnmLago-genesis,
* McsEngl.{HmnmLago'iK2.BpK2x002}-genesis,

genesis of HmnmLago

change of HmnmLago

description::
"Οι γλώσσες δεν χαλούν - αλλάζουν. Όμως μπορεί να χαθούν"
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=120]
"Οι γλώσσες αλλάζουν λοιπόν μέσα στα χρόνια, με διαφορετικούς ρυθμούς και σε συνάρτηση με εξωτερικές, ιστορικές συγκυρίες. Έτσι, άλλαξε η προφορά (και όχι μόνο, όπως θα δούμε σε λίγο) της αρχαίας ελληνικής. Στην αλλαγή αυτή σίγουρα έπαιξε σημαντικό ρόλο η τεράστια γεωγραφική εξάπλωση της ελληνικής, της κοινής, και η συνάντησή της με αλλόγλωσσους πληθυσμούς. Οι πληθυσμοί αυτοί την έμαθαν, γιατί είχε ιδιαίτερο γόητρο ως γλώσσα των κυριάρχων, και τη μίλησαν είτε ως δεύτερη γλώσσα είτε ως μητρική τους (στις περιπτώσεις που οι ομιλητές εγκατέλειψαν τη μητρική τους γλώσσα και έγιναν ελληνόφωνοι)."
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=140]
=== smoothing:
"Τα φαινόμενα που συζητήσαμε ως τώρα δείχνουν καθαρά αυτό που ήδη επισημάναμε: ότι η κοινή δημιουργείται με μια σειρά αλλαγών που έχουν ένα κοινό χαρακτηριστικό: την εξομάλυνση της μορφολογίας των ρημάτων και των ουσιαστικών. Και η εξομάλυνση αυτή κάνει απλούστερη τη δομή της ελληνικής γλώσσας. Και απλούστερη δομή, χωρίς πολλές και περίπλοκες μορφολογικές διακρίσεις (θυμηθείτε τα ρήματα σε -μι, την «ειδική» κλίση ουσιαστικών όπως πατήρ, γυνή, γέρων, χάρων κ.ά.), σημαίνει ευκολότερη εκμάθηση, τόσο από το μικρό παιδί όσο και από τον αλλόγλωσσο που μαθαίνει μια νέα γλώσσα. Και δεν είναι τυχαίο ότι οι μεγάλες αυτές αλλαγές στην ελληνική γλώσσα γίνονται σε μια εποχή που αυτή απλώνεται γεωγραφικά και μαθαίνεται από ξένους."
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=150]

name::
* McsEngl.HmnmLago'change,

descriptionLong::
"Language change is variation over time in a language's features. It is studied in several subfields of linguistics: historical linguistics, sociolinguistics, and evolutionary linguistics. Traditional theories of historical linguistics identify three main types of change: systematic change in the pronunciation of phonemes, or sound change; borrowing, in which features of a language or dialect are altered as a result of influence from another language or dialect; and analogical change, in which the shape or grammatical behavior of a word is altered to more closely resemble that of another word.
All living languages are continually undergoing change. Some commentators use derogatory labels such as "corruption" to suggest that language change constitutes a degradation in the quality of a language, especially when the change originates from human error or is a prescriptively discouraged usage.[1] Modern linguistics rejects this concept, since from a scientific point of view such innovations cannot be judged in terms of good or bad.[2][3] John Lyons notes that "any standard of evaluation applied to language-change must be based upon a recognition of the various functions a language 'is called upon' to fulfil in the society which uses it".[4]
Over a sufficiently long period of time, changes in a language can accumulate to such an extent that it is no longer recognizable as the same language. For instance, modern English is the result of centuries of language change applying to Old English, even though modern English is extremely divergent from Old English in grammar, vocabulary, and pronunciation. The two may be thought of as distinct languages, but Modern English is a "descendant" of its "ancestor" Old English. When multiple languages are all descended from the same ancestor language, as the Romance languages are from Vulgar Latin, they are said to form a language family and be "genetically" related."
[{2023-09-01 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_change]

loan of HmnmLago

description::
"Ο γλωσσικός δανεισμός δεν «βρωμίζει» τη γλώσσα έτσι ώστε να χρειάζεται να την «καθαρίσουμε». Όλες οι γλώσσες, το έχουμε ήδη συζητήσει, διαμορφώθηκαν μέσα από τις επαφές τους με άλλες γλώσσες. Και δεν γίνεται αλλιώς. Οι λαοί και οι γλώσσες δεν κλείνονται σε γυάλες."
[{2022-04-18 retrieved} https://www.greek-language.gr/Resources/ancient_greek/history/ag_history/browse.html?start=162]

death of HmnmLago

description::
"Οι γλώσσες που χάθηκαν στο παρελθόν, που έχασαν δηλαδή τους ομιλητές τους, οι οποίοι μετακινήθηκαν σε μια άλλη ισχυρή γλώσσα, αλλά και αυτές που κινδυνεύουν σήμερα ήταν (και είναι) γλώσσες με λίγους ομιλητές, χωρίς «μηχανισμούς» να τις στηρίζουν: σχολεία, λεξικά, γραμματικές, κράτος."
